Note.P: For a listing of dosage forms and brand names, see Dosage Forms section.

Gen.consider.sec.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin have in vitro activity against Gram-positive aerobic bacteria, some Gram-negative aerobic bacteria, and some anaerobic and atypical micro-organisms.

The following Gram-positive aerobic bacteria are susceptible: Corynebacterium jeikeium, Enterococcus faecium (including Van A [vancomycin-resistant and teicoplanin-resistant] or Van B [vancomycin-resistant and teicoplanin-susceptible strains), Listeria monocytogenes, Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-susceptible and methicillin-resistant), Staphylococcus capitis, Staphylococcus epidermidis (methicillin-susceptible and methicillin-resistant), Staphylococcus haemolyticus, Staphylococcus hominis, Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Staphylococcus simulans, Staphylococcus warneri, Streptococcus agalactiae, Streptococcus pneumoniae (penicillin-susceptible and penicillin-resistant), Streptococcus pyogenes and Viridans group streptococci.
The following Gram-negative aerobic bacteria are susceptible: Legionella pneumophila, Legionella species, Moraxella catarrhalis, Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
The following anaerobic bacteria are susceptible: Porphyromonas asaccharolytica.
The following atypical bacteria are susceptible: Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
The following bacteria are considered susceptible using tissue culture methods: Chlamydiae pneumoniae.

In addition, the following bacteria are moderately susceptible to quinupristin/dalfopristin: Gram-positive aerobic bacteria (Enterococcus hirae, Lactobacillus species, Leuconostoc species, Group C streptococci, Group G streptococci) and anaerobic micro-organisms (Clostridium perfringens, Peptostreptococcus species).
The combination of quinupristin and dalfopristin is frequently active against pathogens resistant to beta-lactam, glycopeptide and quinolone antibiotics.
In noncomparative studies, resistance to the antibacterial effects of quinupristin and dalfopristin developed in approximately 2% of patients treated for vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium.

Aus.entry.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin combination is indicated for treatment of suspected or proven methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus or vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infections requiring intravenous therapy and for which other antibiotics are inappropriate.
Quinupristin and dalfopristin combination may be used in patients who are allergic to or intolerant of beta-lactam, quinolone, or glycopeptide antibiotics.

Chem.group.sec.P: Pristinamycin derivatives. Quinupristin is derived from pristinamycin I and dalfopristin is derived from pristinamycin IIA.

Mechan.effect.sec.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin belong to the group of antibacterials known as streptogramins. Individually, each has bacteriostatic activity against Gram-positive bacteria; in combination they are bactericidal. They have high affinity to bind to the bacterial ribosome. In combination, they inhibit early and late phases of bacterial protein synthesis and interact synergistically at the bacterial ribosomal site.

Distrib.sec.P: Apparent volume of distribution for both quinupristin and dalfopristin is approximately 1 litre per kg of body weight.

Unchanged quinupristin and dalfopristin have been shown to penetrate into non-inflammatory blister fluid to concentrations of approximately 19% and 11% of those in plasma, respectively. Penetration of quinupristin, dalfopristin and their major metabolites into blister fluid amounts to approximately 40% compared to concentrations in plasma.

Radiolabelled quinupristin and dalfopristin have been shown to penetrate into ex vivo human macrophages with ratios of intracellular to extracellular concentrations of 60:1 for quinupristin and 30:1 for dalfopristin after one hour. A slow release from macrophages was complete at 5 hours for both quinupristin and dalfopristin.

Biotrans.sec.P: Rapidly converted to several major metabolites, some of which are active. Quinupristin has two conjugated metabolites (one with glutathione and one with cysteine) and dalfopristin has one non-conjugated metabolite (formed by hydrolysis). Synergism of quinupristin’s metabolites with dalfopristin, as well as between dalfopristin’s metabolite and quinupristin, has been demonstrated in vitro.

Section.Head: For quinupristin
Section.P: Mean, 3.2 micrograms per mL following multiple 60-minute infusions of 7.5 mg quinupristin and dalfopristin combination per kg of body weight (mg/kg) every 8 or 12 hours. Area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) was 7.2 micrograms per hour per mL.

Section.Head: For dalfopristin
Section.P: Mean, 7.96 micrograms per mL following multiple 60-minute infusions of 7.5 mg/kg every 8 or 12 hours. AUC was 10.57 micrograms per hour per mL.

Elimination.sec.P: Biliary/faecal, 75 to 77% of the dose (for both parent drugs and metabolites).
Renal, approximately 15% of the quinupristin and 19% of the dalfopristin dose.

In continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD)—Clearance of quinupristin, dalfopristin, or their metabolites is negligible. The plasma AUC of unchanged quinupristin and dalfopristin increases about 1.2 and 1.3 fold, respectively.
In haemodialysis—Because of the high molecular weight of both quinupristin and dalfopristin, it is unlikely that they are removable by haemodialysis.

Note.P: Clearance of both unchanged quinupristin and dalfopristin is 0.7 litre per hour per kg of body weight.

Cross.sens.sec.P: Patients sensitive to other streptogramins (such as pristinamycin or virginiamycin) may also be sensitive to quinupristin and dalfopristin.

Mutagen.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin were not found to be mutagenic in in vitro tests and were not found to be clastogenic in vivo or to induce DNA repair. Tests included the bacterial reverse mutation (Ames test), the CHO/HGPRT gene mutation test, the in vitro unscheduled DNA synthesis test in rat hepatocytes, the chromosome aberration test in CHO-K1 cells and the in vivo mouse micronucleus test in bone marrow.

Dalfopristin was positive for production of structural chromosome aberrations when tested in the Chinese hamster ovary cell chromosome aberration assay, but quinupristin and the quinupristin/dalfopristin combination were negative in this assay.

Pregnancy.P: Adequate and well-controlled studies in humans have not been done.

Studies in mice at doses up to 40 mg per kg of body weight per day (mg/kg/day) (approximately half the human dose based on body surface area) and in rats at doses up to 120 mg/kg/day (approximately 2.5 times the human dose based on body surface area) found no evidence of harm to the foetus. However, administration of intravenous doses ≥6 mg/kg/day was associated with decreased foetal weights and increased post-implantation losses and abortions; although it was thought this could be secondary to maternal toxicity, a ‘no observed effect’ dose was not established. Studies in rats at doses up to 8 mg/kg/day (approximately 0.4 times the human dose based on body surface area) found no effects on the perinatal or postnatal development of rat pups.
Risk-benefit should be considered before use of quinupristin and dalfopristin combination during pregnancy.

Breast.feed.sec.P: It is not known whether quinupristin or dalfopristin is distributed into human breast milk. However, quinupristin is distributed into milk in lactating rats. The manufacturer recommends avoidance of breast-feeding during treatment with quinupristin/dalfopristin.

Paediatric.sec.P: No pharmacokinetic studies have been done in paediatric patients. A small number of children (32) under 12 years of age have received the adult dose of quinupristin and dalfopristin combination in noncomparative “emergency use” studies.

Geriatric.sec.P: Pharmacokinetics of quinupristin and dalfopristin combination have not been found to be different in elderly patients than they are in younger adults.

Note.P: According to in vitro studies, quinupristin/dalfopristin significantly inhibits the hepatic cytochrome P450 3A4 isoenzyme (CYP3A4).

Drug.inter.sec.P: The following drug interactions and/or related problems have been selected on the basis of their potential clinical significance (possible mechanism in parentheses where appropriate)—not necessarily inclusive (» = major clinical significance):

Note.P: Combinations containing any of the following medications, depending on the amount present, may also interact with this medication.

Aus.entry.Entry.term: Medications metabolised by CYP3A4 that prolong the QTc interval, such as:CisaprideDisopyramideLignocaineQuinidine
Aus.entry.P: because quinupristin/dalfopristin has been shown to inhibit CYP3A4 in vitro, there is a possibility that concurrent use could increase the effects of these medications

concurrent use may lead to increased blood concentrations of cyclosporin; in in vitro studies, quinupristin/dalfopristin inhibited metabolism of cyclosporin by CYP3A4; dosage adjustment based on blood cyclosporin concentrations may be necessary

Lab.value.sec.P: The following have been selected on the basis of their potential clinical significance (possible effect in parentheses where appropriate)—not necessarily inclusive (» = major clinical significance):

Aus.entry.P: increases in serum values have been reported
increases in serum concentrations of total and conjugated bilirubin greater than five times the upper limit of normal have been reported in 0.9% and 3.1% of patients, respectively
increases in serum concentrations have been reported
increases in serum concentrations have been reported
increases in blood counts have been reported
increases in blood concentrations have been reported
decreases in leucocyte blood counts have been reported; both increases and decreases in platelet counts have been reported
decreases and increases in serum concentrations have been reported

Contra.med.sec.P: The medical considerations/contraindications included have been selected on the basis of their potential clinical significance (reasons given in parentheses where appropriate)—not necessarily inclusive (» = major clinical significance).

Med.prob.sec.Head: Risk-benefit should be considered when the following medical problems exist

Side.effect.sec.P: The following side/adverse effects have been selected on the basis of their potential clinical significance (possible signs and symptoms in parentheses where appropriate)—not necessarily inclusive:

Side.effect.sec.Head: Those indicating need for medical attention

Present.symp.Symptom: redness, swelling or pain at site of injection
pain, redness or swelling of skin
white patches on mouth, tongue or throat
abdominal or stomach cramps or pain [severe]
lower abdominal or lower back pain

Side.effect.sec.Head: Those indicating need for medical attention only if they continue or are bothersome

Note.P: Incidence of arthralgia and myalgia may be related to duration of treatment with quinupristin/dalfopristin.

Overdose.clinical.Head: Clinical effects of overdose
Overdose.clinical.P: No symptomatic cases of overdose have been reported with quinupristin and dalfopristin combination.

Overdose.treat.Head: Treatment of overdose
Overdose.treat.P: For information on the management of overdose or unintentional ingestion, contact a Poisons Information Centre on 13 1126 (see Poisons Information Centres listing).

Pat.consult.sec.P: As an aid to patient counselling, refer to the Consumer Medicine Information (CMI).
In providing counselling, consider emphasising the following selected information (» = major clinical significance). This information is not intended for distribution to patients.

Aus.entry.P: Check with doctor if no improvement within a few days
If severe diarrhoea occurs, check with doctor before taking any antidiarrhoeals; check with doctor or pharmacist if diarrhoea continues or worsens

Signs of possible side effects needing medical attention, including injection site reaction or venous irritation, skin rash, thrombophlebitis, allergic reaction, oral candidiasis, cellulitis, chest pain, haematuria, infection, palpitations, pancreatitis, paraesthesia, pleural effusion, pneumonia, pseudomembranous colitis, urinary tract infection, urticaria and vaginitis
For other possible side effects that don’t usually need medical attention, see the Side/Adverse Effects section.

Gen.dosing.sec.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin combination is intended for administration by intravenous infusion over a period of 60 minutes.

If moderate to severe venous irritation occurs following peripheral intravenous administration of quinupristin/dalfopristin, options include increasing the infusion volume to 500 or 750 mL, changing the infusion site, or infusing the medication through a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) or a central venous catheter.
If severe or protracted arthralgia or myalgia occurs on the every-8-hour regimen, changing to a 12 hourly regimen may be considered.

Note.P: Dosing and strength are expressed in terms of the combination of quinupristin and dalfopristin base, rather than in terms of their mesylate salts.

Dosing.stmt.P: Intravenous infusion, 7.5 mg (base) per kg of body weight (mg/kg) every eight hours.

Note.P: The intravenous infusion should be administered over sixty minutes.
It is recommended that the vein be flushed with 5% glucose injection following completion of the infusion, to minimise venous irritation.
In patients with severe underlying conditions, use of a central venous access line may decrease the incidence of venous irritation.
If the usual recommended dose is not tolerated in patients with hepatic cirrhosis, dosage reduction to 5 mg/kg is recommended.
Each vial contains sufficient mesylated quinupristin and dalfopristin in the ratio of 30:70 (% w/w) to deliver 500 mg; the specific amounts are 150 mg of quinupristin and 350 mg of dalfopristin.

Preparation.P: Quinupristin and dalfopristin for injection is reconstituted by slowly adding 5 mL of 5% glucose injection or sterile water for injection to the vial and swirling gently (without shaking) to dissolve, producing a solution containing 100 mg of quinupristin/dalfopristin per mL. Solutions of quinupristin/dalfopristin should be not be shaken because excessive foaming may occur. After reconstitution, the solution should be allowed to sit for a few minutes to allow all foam to disappear.

Reconstituted quinupristin/dalfopristin must be further diluted for administration by intravenous infusion. The desired amount of reconstituted solution to provide the intended dose is added to 250 mL of 5% glucose injection. For central catheter infusions, an infusion volume of 100 mL may be used.

Stability.P: It is recommended that reconstituted solutions be further diluted within 30 minutes and the infusion solution used as soon as possible to reduce the risk of microbial contamination. Prior to infusion, the diluted solution is chemically and physically stable for 3 hours at room temperature or 48 hours if stored at 4 °C. It is recommended that the diluted infusion solution not be stored for more than 24 hours at 2 to 8 °C and that it be protected from freezing.
It is recommended that any unused portion of a vial be discarded.

Incompatible.P: Compatibility studies have not been done. It is recommended that quinupristin/dalfopristin not be mixed with or physically added to other drugs. Quinupristin/dalfopristin is not compatible with sodium chloride. Flushing of the line with 0.9% sodium chloride injection or heparin immediately after administration of quinupristin/dalfopristin is not recommended.

If quinupristin/dalfopristin and other drugs are administered intermittently through a common intravenous line, it is recommended that the line be flushed with 5% glucose injection before and after each quinupristin/dalfopristin administration.
